item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive overview of the American television series Resident Alien, detailing its genre, creators, cast, production, and reception. It is based on the comic book of the same name.

Genre ðŸ”—

The series blends comedy-drama, mystery, and science fiction elements.

Created By ðŸ”—

The show was created by Chris Sheridan.

Based On ðŸ”—

The series is based on the Resident Alien comic book series by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse.

Starring ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Alan Tudyk
  • Sara Tomko
  • Corey Reynolds
  • Alice Wetterlund
  • Levi Fiehler
  • Judah Prehn
  • Elizabeth Bowen

Opening Theme ðŸ”—

The opening theme is “Bilgewater” by Brown Bird.

Country of Origin ðŸ”—

The series originates from the United States.

Original Language ðŸ”—

The original language is English.

No. of Seasons ðŸ”—

The show has 3 seasons.

No. of Episodes ðŸ”—

There are 34 episodes.

Production ðŸ”—

Key production details include:

  • Executive Producers: Chris Sheridan, Mike Richardson, Keith Goldberg, Justin Falvey, Darryl Frank, David Dobkin, and Robert Duncan McNeill.
  • Producer: Alan Tudyk
  • Production Locations: Delta, British Columbia, Canada.
  • Running Time: 43â€“46 minutes.
  • Production Companies: Jocko Productions, Amblin Television, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Universal Content Productions.

Original Release ðŸ”—

The series originally aired on Syfy from January 27, 2021, to April 3, 2024. It will move to USA Network for its fourth season.

Premise ðŸ”—

An alien crash-lands on Earth and assumes the identity of a small-town doctor named Harry Vanderspeigle. Initially sent to wipe out humanity, he grapples with the morality of his mission while dealing with human connections and other extraterrestrial threats in Patience, Colorado.

Cast and Characters ðŸ”—

Main ðŸ”—

  • Alan Tudyk as Harry Vanderspeigle: An alien who takes on the identity of a doctor. Tudyk also plays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle, a corrupt doctor. Stuntman Keith Arbuthnot portrays the alien in its true form. David Bianchi portrays Goliath, Harry’s future self.
  • Sara Tomko as Asta Twelvetrees: The doctor’s assistant and a member of the Ute tribe.
  • Corey Reynolds as Sheriff Mike Thompson: The town’s sheriff with a troubled past.
  • Alice Wetterlund as D’arcy Bloom: A former Olympic skier and Asta’s best friend.
  • Levi Fiehler as Ben Hawthorne: The town’s young mayor.
  • Judah Prehn as Max Hawthorne: Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s true alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen as Deputy Liv Baker: The town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrials.

Recurring ðŸ”—

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne: Ben’s wife and Max’s mother.
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy: Asta’s abusive ex-husband.
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay: Asta’s estranged daughter.
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges: The wife of the previous town doctor.
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees: Asta’s adoptive father and a Vietnam veteran.
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper: A government agent.
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan: An Air Force lieutenant working with Agent Casper.
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper: A local bowling alley employee.
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla: Asta’s cousin and lawyer.
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho: A nurse at the clinic.
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle: The real Harry’s estranged wife.
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar: Max’s classmate and friend.
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister: A high-ranking military officer dedicated to hunting extraterrestrials.
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone: The new town doctor.
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42: An octopus who can communicate telepathically with Harry.
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson: Mike’s elderly father.
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker: Liv’s husband.
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach: An “alien experiencer” and podcast host.
  • Justin Rain as Elliot: An archaeologist and D’arcy’s on-and-off boyfriend.
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins: Peter Bach’s son, who was abducted by aliens.
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier: A Grey alien-human hybrid.
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres: A detective who becomes romantically interested in Mike.
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”: The human-alien offspring of “Goliath”.
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”: A Blue Avian alien.
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner: (Season 4)

Guest ðŸ”—

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges: The former town doctor.
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself: A ufologist.
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green: The mayor of Jessup.
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn: A laser physicist and Kate’s cousin.
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom: D’arcy’s mother.
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom: D’arcy’s father.
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle: The real Harry’s estranged daughter.
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell: An art gallery owner.
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor: Asta’s biological mother.
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien.
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop: A member of Max’s alien club.
  • Grace Sunar as Mari: Another member of Max’s alien club.
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker: Liv’s grandmother.
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley: A former military chemist.
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien.
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan: An agent working under General McCallister.

Episodes ðŸ”—

Series Overview ðŸ”—

The series consists of three seasons:

  • Season 1 (2021): 10 episodes, originally released on Syfy.
  • Season 2 (2022): 16 episodes, split into two parts, originally released on Syfy.
  • Season 3 (2024): 8 episodes, originally released on Syfy.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

Details the plot of each of the 10 episodes, including key events, guest stars, and viewership numbers.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

Provides a summary of each of the 16 episodes, divided into two parts, with details on plot developments, character arcs, and viewership.

Season 3 (2024) ðŸ”—

Outlines the storylines of the 8 episodes, highlighting character developments, plot twists, and viewership figures.

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

Chris Sheridan was inspired by the Resident Alien comic books and a personal UFO sighting. Syfy ordered the pilot in May 2018, with Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television developing it. The series was ordered in February 2019, with production in Vancouver and David Dobkin directing the pilot. Robert Duncan McNeill executive produced and directed the remaining episodes.

Casting ðŸ”—

Key casting announcements included:

  • Alan Tudyk as Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle (September 2018)
  • Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler (September 2018)
  • Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, and Alex Barima (January 2020)
  • Elizabeth Bowen (February 2020)

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming locations and schedules:

  • Season 1: September 10, 2020 â€“ October 14, 2020, in Delta, British Columbia.
  • Season 2: August 3, 2021 â€“ April 1, 2022, in Ladysmith and other locations in British Columbia.
  • Season 3: January 30, 2023 â€“ May 2

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 ðŸ”—

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s generally believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The USAF and CIA acquired the site in 1955, primarily for flight testing the Lockheed U-2 aircraft. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a frequent subject of conspiracy theories and a central component of unidentified flying object (UFO) folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. It’s located in southern Nevada, approximately 83 miles (134 km) north-northwest of Las Vegas.

Geography ðŸ”—

This section details the physical location and surrounding areas of Area 51. The original base was a 6 by 10 mile rectangle, part of the larger “Groom box,” a 23 by 25 mile area of restricted airspace. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and eventually connects to State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel, Nevada. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, where many US nuclear tests were conducted. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake. Groom Lake itself is a salt flat used for runways.

History ðŸ”—

The origin of the name “Area 51” is uncertain. The CIA refers to the facility as Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. Other nicknames include “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace is Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and mining operations occurred until the early 1950s. The airfield began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program ðŸ”—

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE, the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. sought a secure testing site. Lockheed’s Kelly Johnson found Groom Lake ideal due to the dry lake bed and surrounding mountain ranges. The CIA acquired the land from the AEC, designating it “Area 51.” Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch.” A survey team arrived in May 1955, laying out a runway and base support facility. The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. By July 1955, the base had a paved runway, three hangars, a control tower, and accommodations for personnel. The first U-2 delivery arrived on July 24, 1955. Regular flights were established between Area 51 and Lockheed’s Burbank offices.

OXCART program ðŸ”—

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. Groom Lake’s facilities were initially inadequate. Construction of “Project 51” began in September 1960, including a new 8,500 ft runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) upgraded base facilities. A 10,000 ft runway (14/32) was built, and an Archimedean spiral was marked on the dry lake as an overrun. Three Navy hangars were erected, and the original U-2 hangars were converted to maintenance shops. Facilities included workshops, storage, administration buildings, a commissary, a control tower, a fire station, and housing. A permanent aircraft fuel tank farm was constructed for the JP-7 fuel required by the A-12. Security was enhanced, and the FAA expanded the restricted airspace. The CIA facility received USAF F-101 Voodoos, T-33 Shooting Star trainers, a C-130 Hercules, a U-3A, a helicopter, a Cessna 180, and an F-104 Starfighter. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived in February 1962 and made its first flight on April 26, 1962. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard ðŸ”—

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2, discussions arose about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962, designated “Q-12,” later renamed the “D-21.” “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The D-21 was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21.” Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965. The first D-21 launch was made on March 5, 1966, with a successful flight. An accident on July 30, 1966, caused the D-21 to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft, resulting in one crew member drowning. Kelly Johnson cancelled the program. The Air Force proposed launching them from a B-52H bomber. The test missions were flown out of Groom Lake, with the actual launches over the Pacific. Several more tests were made, none of which met with success. The D-21B program was cancelled on July 15, 1971. The remaining drones were transferred to the Davis-Monthan AFB Military Storage and Disposition Center.

Foreign technology evaluation ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, the United States tested and evaluated captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, Area 51 hosted Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate their performance and capabilities, pitting them against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT. Comparisons between the F-4 and the MiG-21 indicated that the skill of the pilot was what made the difference. On August 12, 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel with a pair of MiG-17Fs. These MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. The aircraft were given USAF designations and fake serial numbers. The data from the HAVE DOUGHNUT and HAVE DRILL tests were provided to the newly formed Top Gun school at NAS Miramar. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. The Air Force began funding improvements to Area 51 in 1977 under project SCORE EVENT. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program ðŸ”—

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. In 1978, the Air Force awarded a full-scale development contract for the F-117 to Lockheed Corporation’s Advanced Development Projects. On January 17, 1981, the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype, designated YF-117A. On June 18, 1981, Lockheed Skunk Works test pilot Hal Farley lifted the nose of YF-117A off the runway of Area 51. Tactical Air Command (TAC) decided to set up a group-level organization to guide the F-117A to an initial operating capability, the 4450th Tactical Group, which officially activated on October 15, 1979, at Nellis AFB, Nevada, although the group was physically located at Area 51. The 4450th TG also operated the A-7D Corsair II as a surrogate trainer for the F-117A. On October 15, 1982, Major Alton C. Whitley Jr. became the

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_51

item.title: Alien Autopsy (1995 television film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (1995 television film) ðŸ”—

This article discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The program, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, aired on Fox and Channel 4, sparking intense debate before being thoroughly debunked.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the production of the hoaxed footage. Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the film in a 2006 documentary. The autopsy was simulated in a London flat, with artist John Humphreys constructing the alien bodies from plaster casts filled with offal, sheep brains, and raspberry jam. Humphreys also played the role of the chief examiner. Alien artifacts were also fabricated. A homeless man was paid to pose as the original cameraman.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section covers the reception and parody of Alien Autopsy in media. The X-Files satirized the footage, and Fox later aired a special debunking it. A fictionalized version of the film’s creation was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including articles from Skeptical Inquirer and books on the Roswell incident and UFO cover-ups.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources, including an article by Ray Santilli about his story and links to the film’s IMDb page and a YouTube video.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation ðŸ”—

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle and other animals under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon has been linked to paranormal and supernatural explanations, as well as more mundane causes. Mutilations typically involve the removal of organs such as the eyes, tongue, and genitals. Reports of such incidents span the globe, involving various livestock and wild animals. Explanations range from natural decomposition and predation to cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The United States has conducted two federal investigations into the matter.

Early History ðŸ”—

Documented reports of unexplained livestock deaths date back to 1606 in England, where sheep were found slaughtered with only tallow and some inward parts removed. Charles Fort collected accounts of similar mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 ðŸ”—

The unexplained death and mutilation of a horse named “Snippy” in Alamosa, Colorado, in 1967 brought the phenomenon to wider attention. The Pueblo Chieftain published a story about the incident, detailing the horse’s skinned and defleshed head and neck, as well as precise cuts on the body. The lack of blood and a medicinal odor at the scene fueled speculation about extraterrestrial involvement. Wadsworth Ayer’s investigation for the Condon Committee concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips initially attributed the death to a lightning strike. Later, two students confessed to shooting the horse weeks after the incident gained publicity.

Cattle Mutilations 1973â€“1980 ðŸ”—

This period saw a surge in reported cattle mutilations across Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico. Unidentified helicopters were reported in connection with cattle and pig rustling in Western Iowa (April 1973) and Missouri (August 1973).

1973 Kansas Wave ðŸ”—

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. Several butchered cows were subsequently found in the county, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” butcher. By December, law enforcement reported a wave of cattle deaths in seven counties across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, a conclusion disputed by Modlin.

1974 Nebraska Wave ðŸ”—

Reports continued in April 1974 with a mutilated and blood-drained cow in Nebraska. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. Mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, with coyotes blamed. By June, Lancaster County, Nebraska, reported mutilations. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. In August, an unidentified helicopter was spotted shining a spotlight over a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols due to helicopter sightings. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By late August, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when a helicopter was spotted above his field. Authorities cautioned against shooting at aircraft. In September, an autopsy revealed a supposedly-mutilated cow died of bacterial infection. Over 50 law enforcement officials attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, estimating 27 out of 80 cow deaths were suspected mutilations. South Dakota also reported alleged mutilations. Newsweek became the first national outlet to cover the story, reporting 100 cattle mutilated in Nebraska, Kansas, and Iowa since May. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande confirmed mutilation reports in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Minnesota reported mutilations in Kandiyohi, Swift, and Meeker counties.

1975 Colorado ðŸ”—

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting ðŸ”—

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations, attended by about 80 people. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. In May, Valdez reported finding two drugs in a mutilated bull’s remains: Chlorpromazine (Thorazine) to tranquilize the animal and another to clog the blood. In June 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents ðŸ”—

Many mutilation cases have been reported worldwide since 1967, primarily in the Americas and Australia. South America has seen an estimated 3,500 incidents since 2002. Investigators believe many cases go unreported. In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil, in 1988. Theories ranged from homicide to alien abduction.

Characteristics ðŸ”—

Cattle deaths due to natural causes are common. However, ranchers began reporting unusual deaths characterized by missing sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts were described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals were reported drained of blood with no blood at the scene. Howard Burgess noted that nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints have been found near mutilation sites. The “Snippy” case featured an absence of tracks and small holes “punched” in the ground. In Rio Arriba County, New Mexico, a “trail of suction cup-like impressions” was found leading from a mutilated cow.

Laboratory Reports ðŸ”—

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. However, these anomalies are not consistent across all cases. In a case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI involving a bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, the animal displayed “classic” mutilation signs. The liver and heart were white and mushy, with the texture of peanut butter. Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory detected Clostridium bacteria in the heart but could not draw conclusions. Liver samples were devoid of copper and contained high levels of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were light pink and did not clot. The animal’s hide was brittle, and the flesh was discolored.

Helicopter Sightings ðŸ”—

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters reportedly opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. This followed a series of alleged mutilations in the area. In August 1974, residents reported seeing unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. Know County Sheriff Herbert Thompson claimed helicopter sightings were nightly occurrences. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. Authorities ran ads urging ranchers not to shoot at survey helicopters. The National Guard warned its helicopter pilots to fly at higher altitudes. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. After this encounter, cattle mutilations in the region ceased for about five years. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilations.

Official Investigations ðŸ”—

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms ðŸ”—

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger, tasked with investigating possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents and circumstantial evidence but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement. His investigation was dropped when it was determined cattle deaths were not a prelude to a coordinated campaign against elected officials.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation ðŸ”—

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University, but no conclusive results emerged. A $40,000 reward was offered. The US Bureau of Land Management

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle_mutilation

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” which are names given in ufology to humanoid races purportedly from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones. George Adamski is noted as one of the first to report contact with these beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding them often includes telepathy, benevolence, and physical beauty.

History ðŸ”—

This section discusses the historical context and cultural influences related to the Nordic alien phenomenon. David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” associating Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection. These aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal and youthful. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters became less common as the grey alien archetype rose to prominence.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted ðŸ”—

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites). The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends.”

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics and figures in ufology, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books and academic papers.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to Wikimedia Commons for media related to Nordic aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no conclusive scientific detection has occurred, the possibilities range from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and advanced civilizations. The field dedicated to its study is astrobiology.

Context ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the conditions necessary for life in the universe. It starts with the Big Bang and the subsequent cooling of the universe, highlighting the initial lack of elements necessary for life. The formation of carbon and oxygen through stellar fusion is mentioned, as well as the emergence of planetary systems and organic compounds. Abiogenesis and panspermia are presented as potential origins of life. The section also discusses the vastness of the universe, the limitations of current space exploration technology, and the concept of the circumstellar habitable zone (Goldilocks zone). It concludes by noting the potential for past extraterrestrial life and the adaptive capabilities of life on Earth, while emphasizing that habitability does not guarantee the existence of life. Avi Loeb is mentioned for his speculation on the “Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe”.

Likelihood of Existence ðŸ”—

This section explores the debate on whether extraterrestrial life is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous life based on the size and age of the universe, the abundance of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws, citing Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking. The Copernican and mediocrity principles are also mentioned. The Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that a unique combination of factors makes Earth habitable, is presented as a counterargument. The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy. The section concludes by discussing the Fermi paradox, which highlights the contradiction between the high probability estimates of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for their existence. Dennis W. Sciama, Zhi-Wei Wang, and Samuel L. Braunstein are mentioned in relation to the Fermi paradox.

Biochemical Basis ðŸ”—

This section discusses the potential biochemical characteristics of extraterrestrial life. It considers a range of lifeforms from microorganisms to intelligent beings. Non-equilibrium thermodynamics, stars, volcanoes, plate tectonics, and hydrothermal vents are presented as potential energy sources. Water is highlighted as a crucial solvent, though alternatives like ammonia and hydrocarbons are mentioned. The section explores the chemical elements that could compose extraterrestrial life, focusing on carbon and its potential replacements like silicon. The advantages and disadvantages of silicon-based life are discussed. Norman Horowitz is mentioned for his views on carbon-based life. The section also considers the potential for radically different biochemistries, the role of natural selection, and the likelihood of cell membranes. The evolution from simple cells to multicellular organisms is discussed, with Simon Conway Morris’s views on convergent evolution mentioned. Scientists from the University of Oxford are mentioned for their study suggesting aliens may be similar to humans.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the origins of life on Earth and how it may be related to the possibility of extraterrestrial life. It highlights that the conditions on other planets seem too extreme to harbor life, but some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments. Fossil evidence and historical theories have marked environments like hydrothermal vents or acidic hot springs as some of the first places that life could have originated on Earth. The aspects of these harsh environments that make them ideal for the origin of life on Earth, as well as the possibility of creation of life on other planets, is the chemical reactions forming spontaneously.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential for life on other bodies within our solar system. Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. The possibility of microbial life in Venus’s high-altitude clouds is mentioned. Mars is described as a cold, airless desert, but with evidence of past abundant water. The potential for ancient fossilized remains and surviving microbes underground is noted. The gas giants and ice giants are deemed unlikely to contain life, but the possibility of life on moons orbiting these planets is explored. Europa’s subsurface ocean is highlighted, as well as Ganymede and Callisto. Enceladus’s eruption columns are mentioned as a potential source of study. Titan is presented as the only celestial body besides Earth with liquid bodies on the surface, with speculations about lifeforms with different biochemistry.

Scientific Search ðŸ”—

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology is defined as the science that studies life in the universe. The search is carried out both directly and indirectly, with the identification of exoplanets being a key component. The section mentions the number of identified exoplanets and systems as of September 2017 and February 2021.

Search for Basic Life ðŸ”—

This section details the search for biosignatures within the solar system and beyond. It mentions the study of planetary surfaces, meteorites, and telescope data. The controversial report of nanobacteria-like structures in the ALH84001 meteorite is discussed. The Viking Mars landers’ gas emission experiments are mentioned, along with the methane signatures found in Mars’s atmosphere. NASA scientists Carol Stoker and Larry Lemke are mentioned in this context. The Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover are highlighted as tools for assessing past and present habitability on Mars. A group of scientists at Cornell University are mentioned for starting a catalog of microorganisms, with the way each one reacts to sunlight. NASA’s study of meteorites found on Antarctica is mentioned, with the discovery of adenine, guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine. Scientists reported that cosmic dust contains complex organic compounds. Astronomers at Copenhagen University reported the detection of glycolaldehyde in a distant star system. Astronomers reported the first time discovery, in the plumes of Enceladus, moon of the planet Saturn, of hydrogen cyanide.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for extraterrestrial intelligence through technosignatures. Interstellar communications, atmospheric effects, and planetary-sized structures like Dyson spheres are mentioned as potential indicators. Organizations like the SETI Institute are searching for radio waves and laser pulses. The use of artificial intelligence in this search is mentioned. The section also discusses the potential for detecting nitrogen dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution in exoplanet atmospheres. The Kardashev scale is introduced as a measure of a civilization’s energy consumption.

Extrasolar Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the search for exoplanets that may be conducive to life, focusing on terrestrial planets within habitable zones. The number of exoplanets discovered is mentioned, along with the Kepler space telescope’s contributions. The section notes that there is at least one planet on average per star, and that about 1 in 5 Sun-like stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. Proxima Centauri b is mentioned as the nearest known exoplanet. The least massive and most massive exoplanets known are mentioned. The section concludes by noting the importance of planetary habitability in determining the suitability of a planet for hosting life.

History and Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the search for extraterrestrial life.

Cosmic Pluralism ðŸ”—

This section traces the historical development of the idea of cosmic pluralism, the belief in numerous inhabited worlds beyond Earth. It begins with the Ancient Greeks, contrasting the atomist view of Epicurus with the Aristotelian view. Medieval Muslim writers Fakhr al-Din al-Razi and Muhammad al-Baqir are mentioned for supporting cosmic pluralism based on the Qur’an. Chaucer’s poem The House of Fame is mentioned. The section also discusses the association of atomism with atheism and the varying views within the Church. Anaxagoras is mentioned for the term ‘panspermia’.

Early Modern Period ðŸ”—

This section discusses the impact of the Copernican Revolution and the invention of the telescope on the concept of extraterrestrial life. Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo Galilei are mentioned for their contributions to the heliocentric model. Galileo’s trial for heresy is noted. Giordano Bruno is highlighted as an early proponent of extraterrestrial life, who was tried and executed for his beliefs. Isaac Newton’s theory of gravity is mentioned as further strengthening the heliocentric model.

19th Century ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 19th-century speculation about life on Mars, fueled by telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell is mentioned for his books proposing that the canals were the work of a civilization. William Wallace Campbell is mentioned for his spectroscopic analysis of Mars’s atmosphere. Louis Pasteur’s disproving of spontaneous generation is noted. JÃ¶ns Jacob Berzelius, Kelvin, Hermann von Helmholtz, and Svante Arrhenius are mentioned for their panspermia theory. The development of science fiction is mentioned.

Recent History ðŸ”—

This section discusses the emergence of astrobiology as a distinct science. NASA, ESA, and INAF are mentioned as organizations studying astrobiology. The limitations of studying only Earth-based life are noted. The rise of pseudoscience, such as ufology and ancient astronauts, is mentioned. Lewis White Beck is mentioned for tracing the evolution of philosophical thought. The section concludes by noting the advances in planetary habitability knowledge, astronomy, and spacecraft technology. Frank Drake and Jacques Monod are mentioned. Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee are mentioned for their book Rare Earth: Why Complex Life is Uncommon in the Universe.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts ðŸ”—

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in various religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeology and unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed evidence. Some argue that these theories have racist undertones, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Key Points:

  • Extraterrestrial contact in ancient times
  • Influence on human civilization
  • Deities as extraterrestrials
  • Dismissal by academics as pseudoscience
  • Potential racist implications

Important People:

  • Robert Charroux
  • Jacques Bergier
  • Jean Sendy
  • Erich von DÃ¤niken
  • Alexander Kazantsev
  • Zecharia Sitchin
  • Robert K. G. Temple
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos
  • David Hatcher Childress
  • Peter Kolosimo
  • Mauro Biglino

Overview ðŸ”—

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers often assert that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the distant past. They propose that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Additionally, they claim that extraterrestrials built or assisted in building structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Proponents cite documentary gaps in historical and archaeological records and point to archaeological artifacts they consider anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These artifacts, sometimes called “out-of-place artifacts,” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact or technologies.

Key Points:

  • Alternative terms for ancient astronaut theories
  • Humans as descendants or creations of extraterrestrials
  • Extraterrestrial origin of human knowledge and culture
  • Extraterrestrial involvement in building ancient structures
  • Use of “out-of-place artifacts” as evidence

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents ðŸ”—

Paleocontact narratives first appeared in early science fiction in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and the success of Erich von DÃ¤niken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von DÃ¤niken’s claims. By the early 1980s, the idea had little remaining support.

Key Points:

  • Origins in early science fiction
  • Rise in popularity in the 1960s
  • Criticism and decline in the 1970s and 1980s

Shklovskii and Sagan ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky in 1966. Sagan later expressed disapproval of writers like von DÃ¤niken who treated speculations about ancient astronauts as valid evidence. Sagan acknowledged the possibility of extraterrestrial visits but emphasized that they were unproven and improbable.

Key Points:

  • Sagan and Shklovsky’s influence on ancient astronaut theories
  • Sagan’s disapproval of uncritical writers
  • Emphasis on the lack of evidence for extraterrestrial visits

Erich von DÃ¤niken ðŸ”—

Erich von DÃ¤niken became a leading proponent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? He argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures, suggesting they were constructed by extraterrestrials or humans who learned from them. These artifacts include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries. Von DÃ¤niken interpreted ancient art and iconography as illustrations of air and space vehicles, non-human creatures, and advanced technology. He also suggested that geographically separated cultures shared artistic themes, implying a common extraterrestrial origin. He interpreted the sarcophagus lid of Maya ruler Pacal the Great as depicting an astronaut. He viewed the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, with humans considering alien technology supernatural and the aliens themselves as gods.

Key Points:

  • Von DÃ¤niken’s role as a leading proponent
  • Argument that certain artifacts required advanced technology
  • Interpretation of ancient art as evidence of extraterrestrial contact
  • View of religions as reactions to alien encounters

Important People:

  • Erich von DÃ¤niken

Locations:

  • Stonehenge
  • Pumapunku
  • Easter Island
  • Great Pyramid of Giza
  • Baghdad

Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of ancient Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which he claimed the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet.” Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of the Anunnaki, inhabitants of Nibiru, who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens, the Adapa or Adam of later mythology.

Key Points:

  • Sitchin’s interpretation of Sumerian texts
  • Hypothesis of the Anunnaki from Nibiru
  • Genetic engineering of humans by the Anunnaki

Important People:

  • Zecharia Sitchin

Locations:

  • Mesopotamia

Robert Temple ðŸ”—

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cited advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations.

Key Points:

  • Temple’s argument about the Dogon people’s knowledge of extraterrestrial visitation
  • Citing advanced astronomical knowledge and comparative belief systems

Important People:

  • Robert K. G. Temple
  • Marcel Griaule
  • Germaine Dieterlen

Locations:

  • Mali

UFO Religions ðŸ”—

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, RaÃ«lism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many of these faiths see both ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens from other planetary systems.

Key Points:

  • Belief in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence
  • Connection between ancient scriptures and alien actions

Organizations:

  • Theosophy
  • Scientology
  • RaÃ«lism
  • Aetherius Society
  • Heaven’s Gate

Claims of Proponents ðŸ”—

Scientists generally view the ancient astronaut hypothesis as unjustified and unnecessary, as the “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts.

Key Points:

  • Scientific consensus against the ancient astronaut hypothesis
  • Unnecessary nature of the hypothesis

Ancient Religious Texts ðŸ”—

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, interpreting creation myths of gods descending from the heavens as representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to modern cargo cults, where isolated cultures believe Western ships and cargo are sent from the gods.

Key Points:

  • Interpretation of ancient creation myths as alien visits
  • Analogy to modern cargo cults

Ramayana ðŸ”—

In Hindu mythology, gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana contains mentions of these flying objects. Erich von DÃ¤niken suggests that the vimanas were “space vehicles.”

Key Points:

  • Mentions of flying vehicles (Vimana) in the Ramayana
  • Von DÃ¤niken’s interpretation of vimanas as space vehicles

Locations:

  • Ayodhya
  • Sri Lanka

The Bible ðŸ”—

Book of Genesis and Book of Enoch ðŸ”—

The Book of Genesis mentions the “sons of God” marrying human women and the Nephilim. The Book of Enoch expands on this, describing the “sons of God” as angels who descended to Earth to breed with humans. Some ancient astronaut proponents argue that this is a historical account of extraterrestrials visiting Earth, called Watchers, who made contact with humans, cross-bred with human females, and shared knowledge with them.

Key Points:

  • Interpretation of Genesis and Enoch as accounts of extraterrestrial contact
  • Watchers as extraterrestrials who cross-bred with humans
  • Nephilim as half-human-half-extraterrestrial hybrids
Book of ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 ðŸ”—

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited ðŸ”—

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies ðŸ”—

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the United States ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of reported UFO sightings within the United States, presented in a table format. Each entry includes the date, city, state, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details specific instances of alleged UFO sightings, arranged chronologically.

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported a craft crash, describing sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.

  • 1896â€“1897, Multiple Locations: Sightings of airship-like vehicles were reported across the United States, known as the Mystery airships.

  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery, known as the Aurora, Texas, UFO incident.

  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles” involved an alleged enemy attack and anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Initially thought to be from Japan, it was later attributed to “war nerves” and a lost weather balloon. Key figures include Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox.

  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported an “avocado-shaped” object crashing, with insect-like alien creatures inside, known as the Trinity UFO Case.

  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: An incident occurred before the Kenneth Arnold sighting, involving an alleged encounter with “men in black.”

  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation, describing them as bright and moving at “tremendous speed.”

  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident involved the recovery of materials near Roswell, sparking speculation about a crashed alien craft versus a top-secret research balloon.

  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident involved the death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while pursuing a UFO. Historian David Michael Jacobs noted this case marked a shift in public and governmental perceptions of UFOs.

  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involved two commercial pilots reporting a near collision with a strange torpedo-shaped object.

  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight involved a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.

  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: The McMinnville UFO photographs were taken by Paul and Evelyn Trent on a farm.

  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”

  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention.

  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.

  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and friendly pilots during his drives home.

  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved multiple reports of unidentified flying objects over the city.

  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported seeing a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature, known as the Flatwoods monster.

  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.

  • November 2, 1957, Levelland, Texas: The Levelland UFO case involved multiple sightings of a UFO in the small town.

  • September 19, 1961, Lancaster, New Hampshire: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials, known as the Betty and Barney Hill abduction.

  • April 24, 1964, Socorro, New Mexico: Lonnie Zamora, a New Mexico police officer, reported a UFO close encounter, known as the Lonnie Zamora incident.

  • September 3, 1965, Exeter, New Hampshire: The Exeter incident involved a large UFO seen by a teenager and two police officers.

  • December 9, 1965, Kecksburg, Pennsylvania: The Kecksburg UFO incident involved a large fireball seen over multiple states and Ontario, Canada.

  • 1969, Leary, Georgia: Jimmy Carter claimed to have seen a UFO.

  • October 11, 1973, Pascagoula, Mississippi: Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker reported being abducted, known as the Pascagoula Abduction.

  • January 12, 1975, North Bergen, New Jersey: An incident occurred near the Stonehenge apartment building, known as the Stonehenge incident.

  • November 5, 1975, Snowflake, Arizona: Travis Walton claimed to have been abducted by a UFO, known as the Travis Walton UFO incident.

  • December 17, 1977, Council Bluffs, Iowa: Residents reported a reddish fireball and a grass fire with molten metal.

  • August 27, 1979, Stephen, Minnesota: Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a ball of light, known as the Val Johnson incident.

  • December 29, 1980, Dayton, Texas: The Cash-Landrum Incident involved a UFO sighting and subsequent health issues for the witnesses.

  • November 11, 1987, Gulf Breeze, Florida: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident occurred.

  • March 8, 1994, Michigan: Over 100 witnesses reported multiple objects, known as the 1994 Lake Michigan UFO event.

  • March 13, 1997, Phoenix, Arizona: The Phoenix Lights involved a series of optical phenomena seen by thousands of people. Former Arizona governor Fife Symington admitted to seeing a delta-shaped craft.

  • January 5, 2000, Highland, Illinois: The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting involved multiple police officers and witnesses reporting a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.

  • August 21, 2004, Chicago, Illinois: A triangular formation of reddish lights was seen by hundreds of witnesses.

  • November 7, 2006, Chicago, Illinois: Employees at Chicago O’Hare International Airport reported a metallic, saucer-shaped craft, known as the Chicago O’Hare UFO sighting 2006.

  • January 5, 2009, Morristown, New Jersey: Five unidentified red objects were seen. Joe Rudy and Chris Russo later admitted it was a hoax, known as the Morristown UFO.

  • February 19, 2018, Arizona Desert: Commercial pilots saw an unidentified object, later attributed to a “high-altitude research balloon.”

  • February 21, 2021, Clayton, New Mexico: A pilot reported seeing a long cylindrical object.

  • February 10, 2023, Deadhorse, Alaska: A high-altitude object was shot down over the Beaufort Sea, known as the 2023 Alaska high-altitude object.

  • February 12, 2023, Lake Huron, Michigan: An octagonal object was shot down over Lake Huron, known as the 2023 Lake Huron high-altitude object.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related articles, including a general list of reported UFO sightings and an article on psychological perspectives on UFO belief.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to external websites and publications.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to UFO sightings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_the_United_States

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon ðŸ”—

The Dover Demon is a creature reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as about 4 feet tall with glowing orange eyes and no nose or mouth, with a watermelon-shaped head. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature the following night on Springdale Avenue. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing on a stack of Bibles to the accuracy of his drawing. The locations of the sightings, when plotted on a map, formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, and a local investigator noted similarities to the creatures in the Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter. The Mutual UFO Network also investigated the sightings.

Possible explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size and plumage, which could reflect yellow headlights. The “long spindly arms” could be the partially opened wings of the owl. Police suggested the sightings were a school vacation hoax. Ben Radford suggests the sightings may have been influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in an episode of the American horror television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet in 2009. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof, where it can see into the future, and in The Perhapanauts. It also made appearances in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. A Dover Demon appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. In the manga series Dandadan, an alien known as Dover Demon takes the form of a bipedal crustacean-like alien.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon
